citations.narrative:
At the time of the inspection, two of the 10 adult dogs at the facility were not listed on the inventory (APHIS 7005 form). In
addition, a puppy cage card used for documenting the inventory of 5 weaned puppies (housed as a litter) at the facility did
not include the identification numbers for those puppies. The puppies had recently been microchipped. Neither the
puppies originally assigned identification numbers, nor their microchip numbers were listed on the cage card. Records
provide an important source of information for the identification of each and every animal at the facility. Records can be
important for tracing animals.
The licensee shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose required information
concerning all dogs purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under
his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of. Among other required components
listed in 2.75(a)(1)(i)-(ix), the records shall include the official USDA number assigned to each dog or puppy.
To be corrected by close of business on 3/25/2025

At the time of inspection, the licensee had not reviewed the contingency plan at least annually as evidenced by an
undocumented change in the attending veterinarian in 2024 and absence of documentation of review of the contingency
plan in 2024. Timely review of the contingency plan helps ensure that needed changes are made that could help prevent
animal discomfort, illness, injury or death in the event of an emergency or disaster.
The licensee must ensure that the contingency plan is reviewed on at least an annual basis to ensure that it addresses
the criteria listed in Section 2.34(a) and must also maintain documentation of those reviews, to include any amendments
or changes made to the plan since the previous year's review.
To be corrected by close of business on 4/1/2025.

At the time of the inspection, there was a plastic five-gallon bucket of dog food being stored in the main sheltered
enclosure building with no lid. Uncovered dog food could spoil or become contaminated by exposure to the environment
or pests such as flies and mice.
Supplies of food and bedding must be stored in a manner that protects the supplies from spoilage, contamination, and
vermin infestation. All open supplies of food and bedding must be kept in leakproof containers with tightly fitting lids to
prevent contamination and spoilage.
To be corrected by close of business on 3/25/2025

At the time of the inspection, numerous primary enclosures housing dogs or puppies were not maintained to prevent injury
to the dogs. First, the outdoor portion of one sheltered enclosure housing 5 puppies had large holes (approximately 6
inches in diameter) hollowed out below the sheltered portion of the building. This same enclosure had a feeding dispenser
setting loose on the ground in the outdoor portion of the enclosure. Second, the outdoor portion of several (at least 3)
other enclosures housing adult dogs also had large holes (3-6 inches in diameter) hollowed out below the sheltered
portion of the building. Third, the wire dig barrier was exposed and loosened from the ground in the outside portion of two
enclosures housing adult dogs. Finally, the outdoor portion of one enclosure housing an adult dog had a worn and frayed
piece of carpet with loose strings coming off the carpet. All the described conditions create opportunity for a dog or puppy
or an appendage to become entangled or entrapped, which could lead to injury, pain or distress.
The licensee must ensure that primary enclosures are maintained to protect dogs from injury. Specifically, loose and worn
articles that could cause injury must be removed from primary enclosures in a timely manner. Second, holes that could
cause injury must be repaired. Finally, materials that are part of the construction of the enclosure must be maintained to
prevent injury.
To be corrected by close of business on 4/1/2025

At the time of inspection, the license did not have a documented exercise plan approved by the attending veterinarian. An
exercise plan is necessary to ensure that dogs are provided with adequate space and opportunity for exercise for their
health and well-being.
The licensee must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide dogs with the opportunity for exercise. In
addition, the plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian.
To be corrected by close of business on 4/15/2025.

At the time of the inspection, the program of veterinary care for dogs made avaialbe was not signed by the facility’s
current attending veterinarian. A program of veterinary care signed by the attending veterinarian is important to ensuring
that both the veterinarian and the licensee have a clear understanding of their respective roles and to ensuring dogs at
the facility receive appropriate preventive and medical care.
The licensee must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented in writing, and
signed by the attending veterinarian.
To be correct by close of business on 4/15/2025.

At the time of the inspection, the licensee did not have certain required medical records. The program of vet care from the
previous attending veterinarian and the one reported by the licensee as the program of veterinary care being implemented
required the following: 1) deworming of adult dogs 3-6 times per year with pyrantel or fenbendazole, 2) annual vaccination
of adults for distemper and parvovirus 3) optional vaccination for leptospirosis, adenovirus type 2, parainfluenza, and
Bordetella, 4) cleaning of ears every 3 to 4 weeks or more frequently as needed, 5) Tramming of hair, nails, and grooming
every 4 to 6 weeks. The licensee indicated he was following these procedures as required by the program of veterinary
care, but he was not documenting them. Medical records are essential for APHIS inspectors to evaluate the quality of
medical care provided by the facility and ensure the animals are protected from disease, injury, and illness.
The licensee must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make the records available for APHIS inspection. These
records must include routine husbandry procedures, such as vaccinations, preventive medical procedures, or treatments,
performed on all animals.
To be corrected by the close of business on 3/25/2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.75(a)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
At the time of the inspection, two of the 10 adult dogs at the facility were not listed on the inventory (APHIS 7005 form). In 
addition, a puppy cage card used for documenting the inventory of 5 weaned puppies (housed as a litter) at the facility did 
not include the identification numbers for those puppies. The puppies had recently been microchipped. Neither the 
puppies originally assigned identification numbers, nor their microchip numbers were listed on the cage card. Records 
provide an important source of information for the identification of each and every animal at the facility. Records can be 
important for tracing animals.  
 
The licensee shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose required information 
concerning all dogs purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under 
his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of. Among other required components 
listed in 2.75(a)(1)(i)-(ix), the records shall include the official USDA number assigned to each dog or puppy. 
 
To be corrected by close of business on 3/25/2025 
2.134(b) 
   
Contingency planning. 
At the time of inspection, the licensee had not reviewed the contingency plan at least annually as evidenced by an 
undocumented change in the attending veterinarian in 2024 and absence of documentation of review of the contingency 
plan in 2024. Timely review of the contingency plan helps ensure that needed changes are made that could help prevent 
animal discomfort, illness, injury or death in the event of an emergency or disaster.  
 
The licensee must ensure that the contingency plan is reviewed on at least an annual basis to ensure that it addresses 
the criteria listed in Section 2.34(a) and must also maintain documentation of those reviews, to include any amendments 
or changes made to the plan since the previous year's review. 
 
To be corrected by close of business on 4/1/2025. 
3.1(e)

Housing facilities, general. 
At the time of the inspection, there was a plastic five-gallon bucket of dog food being stored in the main sheltered 
enclosure building with no lid. Uncovered dog food could spoil or become contaminated by exposure to the environment 
or pests such as flies and mice.  
 
Supplies of food and bedding must be stored in a manner that protects the supplies from spoilage, contamination, and 
vermin infestation. All open supplies of food and bedding must be kept in leakproof containers with tightly fitting lids to 
prevent contamination and spoilage. 
 
To be corrected by close of business on 3/25/2025 
3.6(a)(2)(ii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
At the time of the inspection, numerous primary enclosures housing dogs or puppies were not maintained to prevent injury 
to the dogs. First, the outdoor portion of one sheltered enclosure housing 5 puppies had large holes (approximately 6 
inches in diameter) hollowed out below the sheltered portion of the building. This same enclosure had a feeding dispenser 
setting loose on the ground in the outdoor portion of the enclosure. Second, the outdoor portion of several (at least 3) 
other enclosures housing adult dogs also had large holes (3-6 inches in diameter) hollowed out below the sheltered 
portion of the building. Third, the wire dig barrier was exposed and loosened from the ground in the outside portion of two 
enclosures housing adult dogs. Finally, the outdoor portion of one enclosure housing an adult dog had a worn and frayed 
piece of carpet with loose strings coming off the carpet. All the described conditions create opportunity for a dog or puppy 
or an appendage to become entangled or entrapped, which could lead to injury, pain or distress. 
 
The licensee must ensure that primary enclosures are maintained to protect dogs from injury. Specifically, loose and worn 
articles that could cause injury must be removed from primary enclosures in a timely manner. Second, holes that could 
cause injury must be repaired. Finally, materials that are part of the construction of the enclosure must be maintained to 
prevent injury. 
 
To be corrected by close of business on 4/1/2025 
3.8 
   
Exercise for dogs. 
At the time of inspection, the license did not have a documented exercise plan approved by the attending veterinarian. An 
exercise plan is necessary to ensure that dogs are provided with adequate space and opportunity for exercise for their 
health and well-being. 
 
The licensee must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide dogs with the opportunity for exercise. In 
addition, the plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian. 
 
To be corrected by close of business on 4/15/2025.

3.13(a) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
At the time of the inspection, the program of veterinary care for dogs made avaialbe was not signed by the facility’s 
current attending veterinarian. A program of veterinary care signed by the attending veterinarian is important to ensuring 
that both the veterinarian and the licensee have a clear understanding of their respective roles and to ensuring dogs at 
the facility receive appropriate preventive and medical care. 
 
The licensee must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented in writing, and 
signed by the attending veterinarian. 
 
To be correct by close of business on 4/15/2025. 
3.13(b) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
At the time of the inspection, the licensee did not have certain required medical records. The program of vet care from the 
previous attending veterinarian and the one reported by the licensee as the program of veterinary care being implemented 
required the following: 1) deworming of adult dogs 3-6 times per year with pyrantel or fenbendazole, 2) annual vaccination 
of adults for distemper and parvovirus 3) optional vaccination for leptospirosis, adenovirus type 2, parainfluenza, and 
Bordetella, 4) cleaning of ears every 3 to 4 weeks or more frequently as needed, 5) Tramming of hair, nails, and grooming 
every 4 to 6 weeks. The licensee indicated he was following these procedures as required by the program of veterinary 
care, but he was not documenting them. Medical records are essential for APHIS inspectors to evaluate the quality of 
medical care provided by the facility and ensure the animals are protected from disease, injury, and illness. 
 
The licensee must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make the records available for APHIS inspection. These 
records must include routine husbandry procedures, such as vaccinations, preventive medical procedures, or treatments, 
performed on all animals. 
 
To be corrected by the close of business on 3/25/2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
